page.title: 10Bell Wharf
page.content: Bell Wharf is a platform that juts out into the sea. In the 1800's there was a pub called The Bell. It was owned by a man called Laurence Lazarus. He built a sloping landing place to get his drinks for his pub. Boats used to bring all he needed to this landing place. The fishermen used it for hauling their fish off their boats. The pub was knocked down to make way for the railway. The rubble from the pub was used to make the sloping platform bigger. That is why it is called Bell Wharf. When we went to visit it, we met the Foreshore Inspector, Mr D Jones, who looks after the foreshore from Chalkwell to Two Tree Island. We saw a boat lifted out of the water for inspection. Fishing and pleasure boats now use Bell Wharf. By Nicola Daniels, Hannah Latham(9yr)
